resources.string: Known as the "king of the jungle," lions are social big cats that live in groups called prides. They are found in Africa and parts of India.
The largest of the big cats, tigers are solitary predators with distinctive orange coats and black stripes. They primarily live in Asia.
The largest land animals, elephants are known for their intelligence, long trunks, and strong social bonds. They are found in Africa and Asia.
The tallest land animals, giraffes have long necks and legs, and distinctive spotted patterns. They are native to Africa.
Known for their black and white stripes, zebras are social animals that live in herds. They are found in Africa.
Large primates that live in family groups called troops, gorillas are known for their strength and gentle nature. They inhabit the forests of central Africa.
Closely related to humans, chimpanzees are intelligent primates known for their complex social behaviors and tool use. They live in Africa.
Agile and elusive big cats, leopards have spotted coats and are skilled climbers. They are found in Africa and parts of Asia.
The fastest land animals, cheetahs have slender bodies built for speed and are found in Africa and parts of Iran.
Large, thick-skinned herbivores with one or two horns on their snouts, rhinos are found in Africa and Asia.
Large, semi-aquatic mammals with barrel-shaped bodies, hippos are known for their aggressive behavior and are found in Africa.
Large reptiles with powerful jaws, crocodiles are found in tropical regions around the world and are excellent swimmers.
Similar to crocodiles but with broader snouts, alligators are found in the southeastern United States and China.
Marsupials native to Australia, kangaroos are known for their powerful hind legs and hopping locomotion.
Tree-dwelling marsupials native to Australia, koalas are known for their diet of eucalyptus leaves and slow movements.
Large bears with distinctive black and white markings, pandas primarily eat bamboo and are native to China.
Large, brown-furred bears found in North America, grizzlies are known for their strength and are a subspecies of the brown bear.
The largest land carnivores, polar bears are well-adapted to life in the Arctic, with thick fur and a layer of fat for insulation.
Social canines that live in packs, wolves are found in various habitats across the Northern Hemisphere and are known for their hunting skills.
Small to medium-sized canines with bushy tails and pointed ears, foxes are found worldwide and are known for their cunning nature.
Herbivorous mammals with antlers (usually on males), deer are found in various habitats around the world.
The largest members of the deer family, moose have long legs and large, palmate antlers. They are found in northern regions of North America and Eurasia.
Large birds of prey with powerful beaks and keen eyesight, eagles are found worldwide and are known for their hunting prowess.
Nocturnal birds of prey with distinctive facial discs and silent flight, owls are found worldwide.
Flightless birds adapted to life in the water, penguins are primarily found in the Southern Hemisphere, especially Antarctica.
Intelligent and social marine mammals known for their playful behavior and communication skills, dolphins are found in oceans worldwide.
Diverse group of cartilaginous fish known for their sharp teeth and predatory behavior, sharks are found in oceans worldwide.
Large marine mammals that include the largest animals on Earth, such as the blue whale, and are found in oceans worldwide.
Marine reptiles with streamlined shells and flippers, sea turtles are found in warm and temperate seas worldwide.
Intelligent cephalopods known for their ability to change color and shape, octopuses are found in oceans worldwide.
